text: PATIENT: So what makes you think I may have fallen again?
DOCTOR: Because I can’t, K just mentioned that she thought you did.
PATIENT: Oh.
DOCTOR: But it might have been last time.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah.
DOCTOR: Okay, and I was like just and then she was on the phone, I was like did she mean now or did she mean before?
FAMILY MEMBER: No, because he was in pain; he was in pain.
DOCTOR: Where is your worst pain do you think?
PATIENT: Right here.

DOCTOR: Still. Well, you’ve got some new spots on the bone scan. That’s one of them and upper spine is the other, you know kind of like of like by the neck area. So I don’t think this Xtandi is holding you as much as we’d like.
conv1084_3-snip1.displayed_text:
PATIENT: So what makes you think I may have fallen again?

FAMILY MEMBER: No, because he was in pain; he was in pain.
DOCTOR: Where is your worst pain do you think?
PATIENT: Right here.
DOCTOR: Still. Well, you’ve got some new spots on the bone scan. That’s one of them and upper spine is the other, you know kind of like of like by the neck area. So I don’t think this Xtandi is holding you as much as we’d like.

text: FAMILY MEMBER: But it is holding him, right?

DOCTOR: Some parts of it but I think we have to think about adding something else to the mix here or stopping it. And I just want to double-check. You’re still taking Xtandi? Okay, and are you alternating like number of pills per day or are you just -
PATIENT: Four a day.

DOCTOR: Okay, so you know you don’t have much room to go from that because that’s the max dose. But when you break through from the bone scan it tells me it’s really not working. The stuff that’s being not - you know it’s not in your liver or anything else. Like it’s just still in the bone and you’ve got pain actually suggests we could try a different treatment called Xofigo. And I mentioned this like a while back. This is that radium stuff that Marie Curie discovered many years ago. I don’t know if you guys remember that from elementary school. But it basically kills, you know, cancer in the bones. Well in her case she died because she was carrying too much of it in her pocket. But in patients, it’s now in legit treatment for men with prostate cancer that has gone to bone.
FAMILY MEMBER: Does that look - something you inject, like a pill or capsule or something?

DOCTOR: No, it’s actually, they put an I.V. in you and it comes in a – it’s a liquid. It’s like liquid radiation, and they draw it up and then they just inject it in you. It’s like you know, it’s like in, in over a minute, and it’s once a month for six months. The person that is the expert is the radiation oncology doctor, and that person knows how to regulate obviously radiation. This is a form of radiation.
FAMILY MEMBER: Is that what they did to him before when he went down there? They -
DOCTOR: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER: Where the pain, where the pain was?

DOCTOR: Uh hum, well there, they radiated you from the outside. You laid down and they beamed it to you, right. This is internal. So when they push it in your bloodstream it goes all around and it lands in the area of the bone that has the cancer.

text: FAMILY MEMBER: Is there side effects?

DOCTOR: Oh yeah, there’s always side effects. Because it’s radiation, some of the side effects could be you know reduced or lower amounts of blood cells in your system, so people could get low white cells, red cells, platelets. Those are your three guys that I always watch out for and in some people, it’s a pretty big dip and you don’t come back. Very rare, but it’s a possibility.
FAMILY MEMBER: What do you mean a dip?
DOCTOR: Meaning it destroys too much.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh.

DOCTOR: And there’s no coming back. But you know in terms of how much does that occur, it’s very rare. Could it occur—sure, and I tend to see it in folks who have had a lot of therapy, especially chemo. You’ve had pills and more pills, a little smattering of radiation and a Provenge, and a partridge in a pear tree. So where you are coming in is your bone marrow is not as compromised as a person who had chemo. I’m not saying that you couldn’t get it after chemo, but the perfect person to give it in is a person who is actually having some pain, which you are, a person that otherwise is in good shape, and has a good enough bone marrow reserve, which you do, and it’s not related to any other treatment like steroids and things like that, where if I were to offer chemo, that would be part of the package. Again, not impossible for us to go down the chemo route, but that’s also the next discussion. But for this, I think it’s reasonable to talk to the radiation doctor about it because you’ll want to know pros and cons. So the bone marrow is the thing I always worry about, but for my other patients, and I’ve had many go through it, the other part that it could affect would be your gut. So diarrhea, stomach upset, not so much nausea and vomiting but just more like you know you’ve got the poops kind of thing. But for you it’s obviously something we

DOCTOR: could regulate because you could get Imodium, you know. You could get treatment. A lot of my patients have it during the time around you know the week that you get injected and then nothing else. So that’s kind of where it is. Oh, and if you have cancer that’s not in the bone, like liver or lungs, which you don’t have, but those patients, they don’t; you know they shouldn’t be treated with this medicine because that medicine that I’m thinking about for you is only for bone. So it will not go to liver or anywhere else.
FAMILY MEMBER: So the pain that he’s having -
DOCTOR: Is in bone.
FAMILY MEMBER: And how big of a spot does he have there – on his hip and lower leg, upper leg.

text: FAMILY MEMBER: Steps.
PATIENT: And I noticed you know like the first day that
DOCTOR: Right.
FAMILY MEMBER: Could that trigger?

DOCTOR: Of course. Hey my other guy, you know what he did? He wasn’t going up and down the stairs. He was just working under the tree putting his little village together. Up and down, up and down; he’s got the same symptom as you. So I think –
PATIENT: So this isn’t something that if I give it total rest for -

DOCTOR: Oh I’m sure that it will get better if you give it total rest. But it doesn’t change this discussion that I see new areas of cancer in your bone. Whether that’s causing pain is slightly different because I’m assuming it may. But it could be worsened because you were just moving.

DOCTOR: Uhn-uhn. This stuff that’s liquid goes everywhere in the bone.

text: FAMILY MEMBER: Will this actually take care of the pain, help with the pain – what he’s getting?

DOCTOR: Yes, that’s actually. The indication is two things. One, it actually makes you live longer. That’s a good thing, like Xtandi, you take it because it’s gonna help you live longer. The other thing is it helps with pain and it reduces the pain.
FAMILY MEMBER: Can he take Xtandi with it? Will that help him or is he going to continually take it?

DOCTOR: So those studies are ongoing, and we normally would get – you know we normally do it like in sequence, like well you did that and now that drug doesn’t work, so now we’re on this. And then you did that, and now that drug doesn’t work and you’re on this. So I normally will take you off. So what my suggestion is we take you off of this for now. We get you in to see the radiation doctor, and when he starts you, because it’s a he, it’s Dr. __, he will see you, make sure you know we go through the insurance checks and all this other jazz. Then when he starts, we can figure out whether you want to start folding back in the Xtandi. But for now, I think we’ll just do one at a time because you’re also sensitive to some things. And then you know we get it in you and you’re on that Xtandi it might be too toxic.
FAMILY MEMBER: You might not know what’s making you feel –
DOCTOR: Exactly. So I want to just poison you one thing at a time.
FAMILY MEMBER: Poison
FAMILY MEMBER: chuckles
DOCTOR: Okay?
PATIENT: And the V___

text: PATIENT: But then again, if I’m taking pain medication to hide that pain, is that a good idea because then I’m gonna overextend myself.

PATIENT: I wasn’t on a ladder.
